posts.name: Jaden Bolton
posts.cooked:
Hi there, our team is currently working on Autonomous java PID code for our first FRC competition this season and were running into two big issues. First a little about the robot, it is equipped with mechanum wheels as our main movement system and we are using spark max’s and neo motors with a drive train assembly as our drive system.

When we run our autonomous code our robot begins to spin in a circle and drift across the floor. The wheels seem to be spinning at random even though our code seems to be sound.

When we run our autonomous code our robot begins to spin in a circle and drift across the floor. The wheels seem to be spinning at random even though our code seems to be sound.

When reviewing the riologs during autonomous we see that the battery is browning out anywhere from 100 to 150 times and is trying to pull over 700 volts from our battery at one moment.

When reviewing the riologs during autonomous we see that the battery is browning out anywhere from 100 to 150 times and is trying to pull over 700 volts from our battery at one moment.

We have some ideas already but I wanted to get outside input but if you would like to here our ideas I can put an edit. Also I am attaching the riolog with the voltage and our code for examination.

We keep our autonomous code in RobotContainer.

Robot code Riolog

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: Your code doesn’t seem to be public.

posts.name: Jaden Bolton
posts.cooked: Hi yes, I realized after the fact. I changed it so now it should be visible.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
It might help if you could post a video and also DS logs .

Have you tried running the robot on blocks?

Where does the odometry think the robot is?  Consider putting your odometry pose onto your Field2d .

You should double-check that the wheels have the right CAN ids.

Some notes from your code:

A joystick deadband of 0.5 seems huge.

Looking in your constants file, I see the wheels are a 30" square, which sounds wrong, because your frame perimeter would exceed 120".

Also in your constants file, I see a note that you are not yet accounting for gear ratio in your calculation of EncoderDistancePerPulse .  I recommend you validate this value experimentally.

You don’t actually seem to be using EncoderDistancePerPulse anywhere.

link_counts.title: Driver Station Log File Viewer — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Jaden Bolton
posts.cooked:
Thank you! Here are some video of the bot on on and off of blocks.

Robot off of Blocks Robot on Blocks

And we are currently looking at EncoderDistancePerPulse , but it seems that since were using a RelativeEncoder interface rather than the Encoder package, its unable to understand. Is there a similar method in RelativeEncoder that would perform the same thing?

We’re sure the CAN ids are good for electrical and we will definitely try out putting our odometry pose in our Field2d . Yes the deadband very high, that was an oversight on our part.

Also could you point out where in our constants class our wheels are defined as 30" square?

posts.name: Logan Kippnick
posts.cooked: There should be a method called setPositionConversionFactor. Basically, the encoder multiplies its raw reading by the factor inputted to output the encoder reading in different units. To find this value for your drive motors, you should multiply the wheel circumference (make sure the units used matches the units used by your pose estimation) by the gear reduction.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
Zluxio:

Also could you point out where in our constants class our wheels are defined as 30" square?

Given that you’re using 8" wheels, this makes your frame perimeter at least 136".
